title: Quiz 1: Foundations of Nursing Research
description: Assess your understanding of the core definitions, purposes, and significance of research within the nursing profession.

questions.question: According to Burns and Grove (1999), the scientific definition of 'research' involves a diligent and systematic inquiry. Which of the following is the primary goal of this inquiry?

options.text: To accumulate data for hospital records
To validate and refine existing knowledge and develop new knowledge
To disprove all traditional nursing practices
To ensure nurses stay busy during quiet shifts

questions.explanation: Burns and Grove define research as diligent, systematic inquiry to validate and refine existing knowledge and develop new knowledge.
questions.hint: Think about the progression of scientific understanding.

questions.question: Cormack (1991) defines ___BLANK___ research as research into those aspects of professional activity which are predominantly and appropriately the concern and responsibility of nurses.
questions.explanation: This specific definition delineates nursing research from general medical or health research by focusing on the nurse's professional responsibility.
questions.hint: The type of research specific to your profession.

questions.question: Which of the following are recognized purposes of nursing research? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Increasing the cost-effectiveness of nursing activities
Providing a basis for standards setting and quality assurance
Defining the medical diagnosis for physicians
Barring and defending a professional status for nursing

questions.explanation: Nursing research aims to improve cost-effectiveness, set standards, and defend professional status. Medical diagnosis is a physician's role.
questions.hint: Focus on administrative, professional, and economic benefits to nursing.

questions.question: Nursing research is strictly limited to clinical nursing problems and cannot address educational or administrative issues.
questions.explanation: Nursing research covers clinical practice, nursing education, nursing management, and general nursing experience.
questions.hint: Think about the scope of the profession beyond the bedside.

questions.question: Match the specific contribution of research to its description according to Burns & Grove:

pairs.right: Forecasting the outcome of nursing activities

questions.explanation: Research describes phenomena, explains relationships, predicts outcomes, and validates knowledge.

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the collection of data in a rigorously controlled situation for the purpose of prediction or explanation?
questions.explanation: Treece and Treece define research in this specific way, emphasizing rigorous control.
questions.hint: The general term for the subject of this unit.

questions.question: Arrange the evolution of nursing research focus chronologically:

items.text: Focus on nursing education and the role of nurses
Awareness of the importance of research grows
Increased studies targeted at clinical nursing problems (1970s)
Continued focus on clinical oriented research problems (Current)

questions.explanation: Early research focused on education/roles, shifting to clinical practice in the 1970s.
questions.hint: It started with 'who we are' and moved to 'what we do'.

questions.question:
Review the statement below. What crucial element of a profession does it describe?

'For a profession to be recognized, it must have its own knowledge base developed through scientific research rather than borrowing from others.'

richContent.content: 'Ideally, professional practice must be based on a sound knowledge developed through scientific research.'

questions.explanation: A unique body of knowledge generated by research is a hallmark of professionalism and autonomy.
questions.hint: It relates to being a distinct, self-governing profession.

questions.question: Which of the following are valid sources of knowledge for the nursing profession? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Knowledge comes from education, management, and practice; relying solely on tradition is what research aims to improve upon.
questions.hint: Think about the different domains where nurses work.

questions.question: According to the definition by Treece and Treece, research must always be carried out in a laboratory setting.
questions.explanation: While they mention 'rigorously controlled situations,' critics argue this definition is too narrow because not all research happens in a lab (e.g., social or field research).
questions.hint: Is field research considered valid research?
